Similar Matrices and Diagonalization

Definitions and Basic Properties

Recall the transformation laws from the previous section. We define

Definition. If n×nn\times nn×n matrices AAA and BBB are identical under a change of basis, as detailed previously by

A=P−1BPA = P^{-1} B PA=P−1BP

for some invertible n×nn\times nn×n matrix PPP, then AAA and BBB are similar or conjugate matrices.

Property. As P−1IP=IP^{-1} I P = IP−1IP=I, the only matrix the identity matrix is similar to is itself.

Property. Similar matrices have the same determinant and trace.

Proof. Let A′=P−1APA' = P^{-1} A PA′=P−1AP for similar square matrices A,A′A, A'A,A′ and invertible square matrix PPP. Our goal is to prove that det⁡A′=det⁡A\det A' = \det AdetA′=detA and Tr(A′)=Tr(A)Tr(A') = Tr(A)Tr(A′)=Tr(A).

First:

det⁡A′=det⁡(P−1AP)=det⁡P−1det⁡Pdet⁡A=det⁡(P−1P)det⁡A=det⁡Idet⁡A=det⁡A\begin{aligned} \det A' &= \det (P^{-1}A P) \\ &= \det P^{-1} \det P \det A \\ &= \det(P^{-1}P) \det A \\ &= \det I \det A \\ &= \det A \end{aligned}detA′​=det(P−1AP)=detP−1detPdetA=det(P−1P)detA=detIdetA=detA​

And also:

Tr(A′)=Tr(P−1AP)=Pik−1AkjPji=PjiPik−1Akj=δjkAkj=Ajj=Tr(A).\begin{aligned} Tr(A') &= Tr(P^{-1}AP) \\ &= P^{-1}_{ik}A_{kj}P_{ji} \\ &= P_{ji}P^{-1}_{ik}A_{kj} \\ &= \delta_{jk}A_{kj} \\ &= A_{jj} \\ &= Tr(A). \end{aligned}Tr(A′)​=Tr(P−1AP)=Pik−1​Akj​Pji​=Pji​Pik−1​Akj​=δjk​Akj​=Ajj​=Tr(A).​

Geometrically speaking, the determinant of similar matrices being the same can be intuited by the fact that they both represent the same linear map under different bases (and thus have the same volume scaling effect).

As a linear map has the same trace and determinant no matter what basis its matrix is expressed in, we can speak of a unique trace and determinant for that map.

Property. If uuu is an eigenvector of AAA, then v=P−1uv = P^{-1} uv=P−1u is an eigenvector of A′A'A′.

Proof. Suppose that Au=λuAu = \lambda uAu=λu for some scalar λ\lambdaλ. Then if

A′(P−1u)=λ(P−1u)\begin{aligned} A'(P^{-1} u) = \lambda(P^{-1} u) \end{aligned}A′(P−1u)=λ(P−1u)​

we have

A′(P−1u)=λ(P−1u)P−1AP(P−1u)=λ(P−1u)P−1Au=λP−1uAu=λu\begin{aligned} A'(P^{-1} u) &= \lambda(P^{-1} u) \\ P^{-1}A P^ (P^{-1} u) &= \lambda (P^{-1} u) \\ P^{-1} A u &= \lambda P^{-1} u \\ Au &= \lambda u \end{aligned}A′(P−1u)P−1AP(P−1u)P−1AuAu​=λ(P−1u)=λ(P−1u)=λP−1u=λu​

which proves the statement as every step is reversible.

Property. Similar matrices have the same characteristic equation.

Proof.

Suppose that AAA and BBB are similar: B=P−1APB = P^{-1} A PB=P−1AP for some transformation matrix PPP. We thus have

det⁡(B−λI)=det⁡(P−1AP−λI)=det⁡P−1det⁡(AP−λP)=det⁡P−1det⁡(A−λI)det⁡P=det⁡(PP−1)det⁡(A−λI)=det⁡(A−λI)\begin{aligned} \det(B - \lambda I) &= \det(P^{-1} A P - \lambda I) \\ &= \det{P^{-1}}\det(AP - \lambda P) \\ &= \det{P^{-1}}\det(A-\lambda I) \det{P} \\ &= \det(PP^{-1}) \det(A-\lambda I) \\ &= \det(A-\lambda I) \end{aligned}det(B−λI)​=det(P−1AP−λI)=detP−1det(AP−λP)=detP−1det(A−λI)detP=det(PP−1)det(A−λI)=det(A−λI)​

which is the characteristic equation of AAA.

Diagonalization

Definition. A matrix representing a linear map A:Fn→FnA: \mathbb{F^n} \to \mathbb{F^n}A:Fn→Fn is diagonalizable if its eigenvectors span Fn\mathbb{F^n}Fn.

This means that:

  1. The matrix has nnn linearly independent eigenvectors;
  2. The matrix can be written in the form of a diagonal matrix under a change of basis (as the matrix representation of AAA is diagonal if and only if the basis chosen are its eigenvectors)
  3. The matrix is similar to such a diagonal matrix.

According to the above definition of similar matrices, we also have

D=P−1APD = P^{-1}APD=P−1AP

where DDD is diagonal.

Remark. If the n×nn\times nn×n matrix AAA has nnn distinct eigenvalues, then it must be diagonalizable, as their eigenvectors are distinct and thus linearly independent; however, this is not a necessary condition (i.e. some matrices have repeated eigenvalues but are still diagonalizable).

The above scenario can occur if one eigenvalue corresponds to more than one linearly independent eigenvector: i.e. the system of equations

(A−λI)x=0(A-\lambda I)\mathbf{x} = 0(A−λI)x=0

has a solution space of dim⁡2\dim 2dim2. In other words, there are no defective eigenvalues. This will be clarified with the lemma below:

Lemma. Suppose that a linear map A:Fn→FnA: \mathbb{F^n} \to \mathbb{F^n}A:Fn→Fn has eigenvalues λ1,λ2,...,λr\lambda_1, \lambda_2, ..., \lambda_rλ1​,λ2​,...,λr​, and let B1,B2,...,BrB_1, B_2, ..., B_rB1​,B2​,...,Br​ be the bases of the eigenspaces Eλ1,Eλ2,...,EλnE_{\lambda_1}, E_{\lambda_2}, ..., E_{\lambda_n}Eλ1​​,Eλ2​​,...,Eλn​​ (in that order). Then the union of B1,...,BnB_1, ..., B_nB1​,...,Bn​ form a linearly independent set.

which is zero. This reaches a contradiction, as the vectors vK1,vK2,...vKmλkv_{K1}, v_{K2}, ... v_{Km_{\lambda_{k}}}vK1​,vK2​,...vKmλk​​​ are a basis for EλKE_{\lambda_{K}}EλK​​ and are linearly independent by definition. □\square□

Remark. A consequence of the above lemma concerns defective and non-defective eigenvalues. The lemma essentially states that the eigenspaces of any linear map are all linearly independent; as such, if no eigenvalue is defective - i.e. if the geometric multiplicities sum to nnn - then nnn linearly independent eigenvectors can be found, and the map is diagonalizable. If, however, defective eigenvalues do exist, the map is not diagonalizable.

Theorem. Diagonalization matrix for linear maps. The transformation matrix PPP that maps the matrix AAA, in the standard orthonormal basis of Fn\mathbb{F}^nFn, to the diagonalized basis of nnn distinct eigenvectors of AAA, x1,x2,...,xn\mathbf{x_1}, \mathbf{x_2}, ..., \mathbf{x_n}x1​,x2​,...,xn​ is

P=[x1x2...xn]P = \begin{bmatrix} \mathbf{x}_1 & \mathbf{x}_2 & ... & \mathbf{x}_n \end{bmatrix}P=[x1​​x2​​...​xn​​]

where D=P−1APD = P^{-1} A PD=P−1AP results in the diagonalized matrix

D=[λ10...00λ2...0⋮⋮⋱⋱00...λn]D = \begin{bmatrix} \lambda_1 & 0 & ... & 0 \\ 0 & \lambda_2 & ... & 0 \\ \vdots & \vdots & \ddots & \ddots \\ 0 & 0 & ... & \lambda_n \end{bmatrix}D=⎣⎡​λ1​0⋮0​0λ2​⋮0​......⋱...​00⋱λn​​⎦⎤​

where λ1,...,λn\lambda_1, ..., \lambda_nλ1​,...,λn​ correspond to the eigenvectors x1,x2,...,xn\mathbf{x}_1, \mathbf{x}_2, ..., \mathbf{x}_nx1​,x2​,...,xn​.

This gives us a general process for determining whether a matrix is diagonalizable, as well as determining what that diagonalization is:

  1. Find the characteristic equation of the matrix and determine its roots,
  2. For each root λi\lambda_iλi​, check the system of homogeneous linear equations
    (A−λiI)x=0(A-\lambda_i I)\mathbf{x} = \mathbf{0}(A−λi​I)x=0
    and the dimension of its solution space (which is the dimension of the eigenspace).
  3. Check if the dimension of the solution space (the geometric multiplicity) is equal to the algebraic multiplicity for every λi\lambda_iλi​ - i.e. check if there are defective eigenvalues.
  4. If there are no defective eigenvalues, find nnn linearly independent eigenvectors from the above systems of equations and form PPP as shown above.
